analysis.raw_content:
# Height & Grade - Technical Manual Page

## Height Regulations

### Maximum Height to Roof Peak by Structure Type:

| Structure | Max. height to roof peak |
|-----------|-------------------------|
| Main dwelling on a standard lot with a roof slope ≤12:12 | 30' |
| Main dwelling on a standard lot with a roof slope ≥12:12 | 33' |
| Main dwelling on a substandard or flag lot | 17' |
| Accessory structure in rear or side yard | 12' |
| 2nd-dwelling units | 17' |

## Technical Specifications

### Fig 43 Determining slope of roof
- Shows diagram with 12" run measurement
- Roof slope is the vertical rise in inches for every horizontal distance of twelve inches (called the "run"). It is expressed as rise:run or, in this example 6:12.
- Note: On a drawing this slope might also be represented as: 1:2/6 or 1/2

### Fig 42 Comparison of roof slopes
- Displays five house silhouettes showing different roof slopes: 12:14, 12:12, 12:10, 12:6, 12:3
- Height measured to top of roof material
- Two height limits shown: Height limit = 33' and Height limit = 30'

## Code References
- **Page 46**: 18.12.040 (a) Table 2
- **Page 47**: 18.04.030 (64) (b)

## Page Number
46

## Additional Information
Height allowances enable a variety of architectural styles while preserving the residential scale of our neighborhoods as well as the privacy and natural light available to each lot.
